strike.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to hit or fall against the surface of something
strike.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: She fell heavily, striking her head against the side of the boat.
A snowball struck him on the back of the head.
Several cars were struck by falling trees.
The last rays of the setting sun struck the windows.
strike.translation[0].definitions[0].not: In everyday English, people usually say hit rather than strike:
I hit my head on the shelf.
He was hit by a rock.
strike.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to deliberately hit someone or something with your hand or a weapon
strike.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: She struck him hard across the face.
Paul struck him a blow to the head.
The assassin’s bullet struck home (=hit exactly where it should).
The victim had been struck with some kind of wooden implement.
strike.translation[0].definitions[2].def: if something strikes you, you think of it, notice it, or realize that it is important, interesting, true etc
strike.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: A rather worrying thought struck me.
The first thing that struck me was the fact that there were no other women present.
It struck her that losing the company might be the least of her worries.
You can’t help being struck by her kindness.
strike.translation[0].definitions[2].not: Strike is not used in the progressive in this meaning You say
It strikes me that they are similar
It is striking me that they are similar
strike.translation[0].definitions[3].def: if a group of workers strike, they stop working as a protest against something relating to their work, for example how much they are paid, bad working conditions etc
strike.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: In many countries, the police are forbidden to strike.
They’re striking for the right to have their trade union recognized in law.
strike.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: Guerrillas struck a UN camp, killing 75.
Opponents of the war say that civilian villages have been struck several times.
strike.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to damage or harm someone or something
strike.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: Such prejudices strike right at the heart of any notions of a civilized society.
The scandal seemed to have struck a mortal blow to the government’s chances of re-election.
The law would strike at the most basic of civil rights.
strike.translation[0].definitions[6].def: if something bad strikes, it suddenly happens or suddenly begins to affect someone
strike.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: The plague struck again for the third time that century.
Everything seemed to be going fine when suddenly disaster struck.
strike.translation[0].definitions[7].def: if lightning strikes something, it hits and damages it
strike.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: The temple burned down after it was struck by lightning last year.
strike.translation[0].definitions[8].def: if a clock strikes one, two, six etc, its bell makes a sound once, twice, six etc times according to what time it is
strike.translation[0].definitions[8].not: strike the hour (=strike when it is exactly one o'clock, two o'clock etc)
strike.translation[0].definitions[8].exa: The church clock began to strike twelve.
strike.translation[0].definitions[9].def: to do something that gives you an advantage over your opponent in a fight, competition etc
strike.translation[0].definitions[9].exa: Brazil struck first with a goal in the third minute.
strike.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a period of time when a group of workers deliberately stop working because of a disagreement about pay, working conditions etc
strike.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The government has promised that the army will be called in to help if there is a firemen’s strike.
a six-week strike by railway workers
a national strike against mine closures
strike.translation[1].definitions[1].def: a military attack, especially by planes dropping bombs
strike.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: American aircraft carriers have launched several strikes.
a surprise air strike on military targets
strike.translation[1].definitions[2].def: the discovery of something valuable under the ground
strike.translation[1].definitions[3].def: an attempt to hit the ball in baseball that fails, or a ball that is thrown to the batter in the correct area but is not hit
strike.translation[1].definitions[4].def: a situation in bowling in which you knock down all the pins (=bottle-shaped objects) with a ball on your first attempt
strike.translation[1].note_box[0].sectio: be (out) on strike
Teachers are on strike again this week.
go on strike/come out on strike
An estimated 70,000 public sector workers went on strike.
begin a strike
Dock workers began a 24-hour strike last night.
call a strike
The union threatened to call a strike.
stage a strike
Health workers will stage a two-day strike next week.
end/call off a strike
The strike was called off two days later.
break a strike
Attempts to break the strike failed.
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + strike
a one-day/two-week etc strike
A three-day strike is planned for next week.
an indefinite strike
Workers at the processing plant have begun an indefinite strike.
a long strike
Most teachers wouldn’t be in favour of a long strike.
a general strike
They threatened to call a general strike.
a national/nationwide strike
In April 1984 the National Union of Mineworkers called a national strike.
an all-out strike
The dockers voted for an all-out strike.
a rail/coal/postal etc strike
A rail strike would cause enormous public inconvenience.
a miners’/teachers’/pilots’ etc strike
The transport workers’ strike inflicted serious damage on the economy.
an unofficial strike
Some workers had been sacked for taking part in unofficial strikes.
a wildcat strike
Legislation to curb wildcat strikes will be introduced during the coming parliamentary session.
an all-out strike
The company faces an all-out strike next month.
a bitter strike
The miners finally returned to work at the end of a long, bitter strike.
a damaging/crippling strike
The company now faces the prospect of a crippling strike.
strike + NOUN
strike action
Hospital workers have voted in favour of strike action.
a strike call
The ANC estimated that more than 4,000,000 people heeded its strike call.
a strike ballot
The union is going to hold a strike ballot.
strike.translation[1].note_box[1].sectio: a period of time when a group of workers stop working because of a disagreement about pay, working conditions etc
A teachers’ strike has been announced for next week.
The rail strike has resulted in major delays on roads across the country.
activities such as strikes, or doing less work than usual, as a way of trying to persuade an employer to improve pay, conditions etc
Lecturers voted to take industrial action over their workload.
Prison officers have threatened industrial action.
a short strike, especially one that lasts for one day
Customs officers will return to work today after a twenty-four hour stoppage.
a period of time when a group of workers deliberately work more slowly than usual as a way of protesting about pay, conditions etc
The hospital go-slow comes into effect tomorrow.
The union carried out strikes and go-slows in support of a wage claim.
strike.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a period of time during which a group of workers deliberately stop working because of a disagreement about pay, working conditions etc (strike2)
strike.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Female staff have gone on strike for equal pay.
Lorry drivers have been on strike for three weeks.
strike.translation[3].definitions[0].def: to deliberately stop working for a time because of a disagreement about pay, working conditions etc
strike.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: In many countries, police officers are forbidden to strike.
Dock workers are striking for more pay.
strike.translation[3].definitions[1].def: to make an agreement with someone
strike.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: The US and China have recently struck a deal over trade.
He was trying to strike a deal with an American corporation to build a hotel in the mountains.
strike.translation[3].definitions[2].def: to suddenly find gold, oil etc, especially after you have been looking for it for some time
